Award.AwardTitle: Mating systems and the origins of genetic conflict
Award.AbstractNarration:
Physical and chemical interactions between individuals are a necessary part of normal reproduction, yet in many animals, differing reproductive goals of males and females sometimes leads to a genetic conflict between the sexes. This project uses the power of the well-studied nematode model system, Caenorhabditis elegans, which reproduces primarily via self-reproduction, and its close relative C. remanei, which has separate males and females, to examine the genetic basis of reproductive interactions. This project uses comprehensive genomic and proteomic approaches to identify the genetic bases of male reproductive traits and antagonistic effects in both C. elegans and C. remanei natural isolates, as well as in C. elegans populations that have been genetically manipulated to reproduce via outcrossing instead of self-reproduction.

Reproduction is a defining characteristic of living systems, and understanding the genetic and functional basis of reproductive interactions can provide key insights about the forces that maintain the tremendous diversity that we see in the world. Infertility affects more than six million Americans each year, with many of these cases being caused by mysterious incompatibilities between the perspective parents. Many basic biological functions are conserved across all animals, so identifying the genes and proteins involved in reproductive interactions in these species may yield insights into similar interactions in other organisms, including humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reproduction is a defining characteristic of living systems, and understanding the genetic and functional basis of reproductive interactions can provide key insights in to the forces that maintain the tremendous diversity that we see in the world. Infertility affects more than six million Americans each year, with many of these cases being caused by mysterious incompatibilities between the perspective parents. Many basic biological functions are conserved across all animals, so identifying the genes and proteins involved in reproductive interactions in these species may yield insights into similar interactions in other organisms, including humans.

 

Here we used a model nematode system that includes species that vary in the way that they reproduce, from usually fertilizing their own eggs, which is known as self fertilization, to always needing to mate with another individual to reproduce, which is known as outcrossing. For the first time, we have generated an assembled genome for one of the outcrossing species. This has allowed us to perform genome-wide comparisons between the species so as to identify genes that respond to long term adaptation to differences in mating system.

 

When any outcrossing species mates with its relatives, which can happen for instance in endangered species with very small population sizes, the resulting offspring tend to display reduced vigor. We have identified the genetic basis of the factors that lead to this so called inbreeding depression within these species and have determined that it is very difficult for a species to recover from inbreeding depression once it has been generated. This suggests that it may be difficult for endangered species that rapidly decline from large population sizes to very small population sizes to recover in fitness over the short term.

 

Finally, we have used a novel technological approach called microfluidics to build very small devices that allow us to isolate and characterize the sperm within each of these species so as to better understand the basic biology of fertilization and the molecular interactions between males and females. This approach has allowed us to identify proteins within the sperm that were previously unknown to play an important role in normal sperm function.
